As governor, I‚Äôll make ethics reform and tackling corruption at the state house a top priority because the people of this state deserve honest leadership that cares more about the next generation than the next election.

6/6

7. Strengthen the State Ethics Commission and abolish the House and Senate Ethics Committees so legislators are no longer policing other legislators. 

8. End dark money groups in South Carolina. 5/6

5. End the legislature's role & influence in electing college boards of trustees by moving to a more independent Board of Regents system to oversee all public colleges.

6. Ban lawmakers from voting on bills being lobbied for or against by a member of their immediate family. 4/6

3. Report all PAC expenditures and contributions within 24 hours. 

4. Increase transparency by disclosing all meetings and communications with paid lobbyists. 3/6

Here's my plan:

1. Impose term limits on all legislators - 3 terms for House members, 2 terms for senators.

2. Ban legislators and the governor from raising campaign money during legislative session so they can focus more on doing their job than keeping their job. 2/6

Twenty years of one-party rule has created a culture of corruption at the state house.

Today, I introduced a sweeping anti-corruption plan so the elected officials of this state can start working for the people they represent - not themselves. 1/6

No party is immune to redistricting abuse. Republicans do it in red states, Democrats do it in blue states. That‚Äôs why both parties must come together to take the politics out of redistricting. Candidates should win on their ideas and merits, not bc their party rigged the system.

Overcoming gerrymandering isnt impossible, just extremely rare. Our district was rigged for the GOP by 10 pts and it didnt flip for 40 yrs. When we won, some called it the biggest upset in SC history. Not bc of the types of campaigns we ran, but bc of how the district was drawn.

Fewer general elections favor incumbents, you know, the folks drawing the lines. And when a district is rigged for one particular party, the winner of the primary is usually the most conservative or liberal. That‚Äôs why we have very few moderate politicians anymore.

They have the authority to cut deals with other legislators to make their districts ‚Äúsafer‚Äù so they are less likely to face a tough general election opponent. This results in very few competitive general elections and more competitive primaries.
